LearnNonparam 1.1.8
  • Reference

    examples

    examples.Rmd
    library(LearnNonparam)

    Chapter 1

    Example 1.1.2 

    # See ?Quantile
t <- pmt(
    "onesample.quantile", alternative = "greater",
    p = 0.5, null_value = 75
)

# See ?Table1.1.1
t$feed(Table1.1.1)

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 40
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 9.094947e-13
print(t$ci)
#> [1] 75.0 77.1

    Example 1.2.1 

    # See ?ECDF
t <- pmt("onesample.ecdf")

# See ?Table1.2.1
t$feed(Table1.2.1)

t$plot_ecdf()

    Example 1.2.4 

    # See ?Quantile
t <- pmt(
    "onesample.quantile",
    p = 0.25, null_value = 0, conf_level = 0.90
)

# See ?Table1.2.1
t$feed(Table1.2.1)

print(t$ci)
#> [1] 11 29

    Chapter 2

    Example 2.1.1 

    # See ?MeanDiff
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.mean", alternative = "greater"
)

# See ?Table2.1.1
t$feed(Table2.1.1)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table2.1.1$new,
#     Table2.1.1$traditional
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 16.16667
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.05714286

    Example 2.1.1 - wilcoxon 

    # See ?Wilcoxon
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.wilcoxon", alternative = "greater"
)

# See ?Table2.1.1
t$feed(Table2.1.1)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table2.1.1$new,
#     Table2.1.1$traditional
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 11
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.05714286

    Example 2.3.1 

    start <- proc.time()

# See ?MeanDiff
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.mean", alternative = "greater"
)

# See ?Table2.3.1
t$feed(Table2.3.1)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table2.3.1$treatment_1,
#     Table2.3.1$treatment_2
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 1.675
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.1966589

end <- proc.time()

# time: all permutaions
print(end - start)
#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.170   0.008   0.178


start <- proc.time()

t$n_permu <- 1000

print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.176

end <- proc.time()

# time: 1000 permutaions
print(end - start)
#>    user  system elapsed 
#>   0.022   0.000   0.022

    Example 2.6.1 

    # See ?Wilcoxon
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.wilcoxon", alternative = "greater"
)

# See ?Table2.6.1
t$feed(Table2.6.1)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table2.6.1$brand_2,
#     Table2.6.1$brand_1
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 4
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.9

    Example 2.6.2 

    # See ?Wilcoxon
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.wilcoxon", conf_level = 0.90
)

# See ?Table2.6.2
t$feed(Table2.6.2)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table2.6.2$granite,
#     Table2.6.2$basalt
# )

# Hodges-Lehmann estimate
print(t$estimate)
#> [1] 30.045
print(t$ci)
#> [1] 13.84 47.96

    Example 2.7.1 

    # See ?ScoreSum
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.scoresum", alternative = "greater", scoring = "expon"
)

# See ?Table2.6.2
t$feed(Table2.6.2)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table2.6.2$granite,
#     Table2.6.2$basalt
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 9.752597
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.002164502

    Example 2.8.1 

    # See ?SiegelTukey
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.siegel", alternative = "less", type = "approx"
)

# See ?Table2.8.1
t$feed(Table2.8.1)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table2.8.1$treatment_1,
#     Table2.8.1$treatment_2
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 24
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.7983023

    Example 2.8.2 

    # See ?RatioMeanDeviance
t <- pmt(
    "twosample.rmd", alternative = "greater"
)

# See ?Table2.8.1
t$feed(Table2.8.1)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table2.8.1$treatment_1,
#     Table2.8.1$treatment_2
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 4.666667
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.06349206

    Example 2.8.3 

    t <- pmt(
    "twosample.ks", n_permu = 5000
)

# See ?Table2.8.1
t$feed(Table2.8.1)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table2.8.1$treatment_1,
#     Table2.8.1$treatment_2
# )

t$plot_ecdfs()

    
print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 0.4
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.8052

    Chapter 3

    Example 3.1.1 

    # See ?ANOVA
t <- pmt(
    "ksample.anova", type = "approx"
)

# See ?Table3.1.2
t$feed(Table3.1.2)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table3.1.2$x_1,
#     Table3.1.2$x_2,
#     Table3.1.2$x_3
# )

# F-statistic
print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 3.781445
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.05327082


# Change n_permu first,
# otherwise changing type to permu will use all permutations by default,
# which results in an error because there are too many permutations. 
t$n_permu <- 1000
t$type <- "permu"


print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 11552.89
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.058

    Example 3.2.1 

    # See ?KruskalWallis
t <- pmt(
    "ksample.kw", type = "approx"
)

# See ?Table3.2.2
t$feed(Table3.2.2)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table3.2.2$control,
#     Table3.2.2$preservative_1,
#     Table3.2.2$preservative_2,
#     Table3.2.2$preservative_3
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 17.14286
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.0006605027

    Example 3.2.2 & 3.2.3 

    # See ?KruskalWallis
t <- pmt(
    "ksample.kw", n_permu = 4000
)

# See ?Table3.2.3
t$feed(Table3.2.3)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table3.2.3$product_1,
#     Table3.2.3$product_2,
#     Table3.2.3$product_3
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 8.246588
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.0115


t$type <- "approx"
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.01619109


t$scoring <- "expon"

t$n_permu <- 4000
t$type <- "permu"
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.01325

t$type <- "approx"
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.02152193

    Example 3.3.1 

    # See ?MultiCompT
t <- pmt(
    "multicomp.t", n_permu = 5000
)

# See ?Table3.3.1
t$feed(Table3.3.1)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table3.3.1$location_1,
#     Table3.3.1$location_2,
#     Table3.3.1$location_3,
#     Table3.3.1$location_4
# )

print(t$multicomp)
#>   i j   statistic      p differ
#> 1 1 2  0.02737145 0.9810  FALSE
#> 2 1 3 -1.77914406 0.0894  FALSE
#> 3 1 4 -3.41048230 0.0036   TRUE
#> 4 2 3 -1.80651550 0.0872  FALSE
#> 5 2 4 -3.43785375 0.0032   TRUE
#> 6 3 4 -1.63133824 0.1190  FALSE

t$type <- "approx"
print(t$multicomp)
#>   i j   statistic           p differ
#> 1 1 2  0.02737145 0.978434752  FALSE
#> 2 1 3 -1.77914406 0.090419680  FALSE
#> 3 1 4 -3.41048230 0.002773484   TRUE
#> 4 2 3 -1.80651550 0.085909110  FALSE
#> 5 2 4 -3.43785375 0.002603664   TRUE
#> 6 3 4 -1.63133824 0.118466249  FALSE

# try other scoring! ("vw", "expon")
t$scoring <- "rank"
print(t$multicomp)
#>   i j  statistic           p differ
#> 1 1 2  0.1224745 0.902523250  FALSE
#> 2 1 3 -1.3880442 0.165123590  FALSE
#> 3 1 4 -2.6536139 0.007963489   TRUE
#> 4 2 3 -1.5105187 0.130911128  FALSE
#> 5 2 4 -2.7760884 0.005501725   TRUE
#> 6 3 4 -1.2655697 0.205667180  FALSE
    # See ?TukeyHSD
t <- pmt(
    "multicomp.tukey", n_permu = 5000
)

t$feed(Table3.3.1)

print(t$multicomp)
#>   i j   statistic      p differ
#> 1 1 2  0.03870907 1.0000  FALSE
#> 2 1 3 -2.51608965 0.3210  FALSE
#> 3 1 4 -4.82315032 0.0170   TRUE
#> 4 2 3 -2.55479873 0.3078  FALSE
#> 5 2 4 -4.86185939 0.0162   TRUE
#> 6 3 4 -2.30706067 0.3892  FALSE

t$type <- "approx"
print(t$multicomp)
#>   i j   statistic          p differ
#> 1 1 2  0.03870907 0.99999236  FALSE
#> 2 1 3 -2.51608965 0.31194094  FALSE
#> 3 1 4 -4.82315032 0.01356971   TRUE
#> 4 2 3 -2.55479873 0.29951264  FALSE
#> 5 2 4 -4.86185939 0.01277452   TRUE
#> 6 3 4 -2.30706067 0.38453323  FALSE

# try other scoring! ("vw", "expon")
t$scoring <- "rank"
print(t$multicomp)
#>   i j  statistic          p differ
#> 1 1 2  0.1732051 0.99934385  FALSE
#> 2 1 3 -1.9629909 0.50683497  FALSE
#> 3 1 4 -3.7527767 0.03978340   TRUE
#> 4 2 3 -2.1361960 0.43109997  FALSE
#> 5 2 4 -3.9259818 0.02817015   TRUE
#> 6 3 4 -1.7897858 0.58494735  FALSE

    Example 3.4.1 

    # See ?JonckheereTerpstra
t <- pmt(
    "ksample.jt", alternative = "greater", n_permu = 4000
)

# See ?Table3.4.1
t$feed(Table3.4.1)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table3.4.1$treatment_1,
#     Table3.4.1$treatment_2,
#     Table3.4.1$treatment_3,
#     Table3.4.1$treatment_4
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 145
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.03225

t$type <- "approx"
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.0285154

    Chapter 4

    Table 4.1.1 

    # See ?PairedComparison
t <- pmt(
    "paired.comparison", alternative = "greater"
)

# See ?Table4.1.1
t$feed(Table4.1.1)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table4.1.1$recall_24h,
#     Table4.1.1$survey
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 168
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.09375

t$n_permu <- 4000
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.10075

    Table 4.1.3 

    # See ?PairedComparison
t <- pmt(
    "paired.comparison", alternative = "two_sided", n_permu = 4000
)

# See ?Table4.1.3
t$feed(Table4.1.3)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table4.1.3$drug_1,
#     Table4.1.3$drug_2
# )

print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.023

t$type <- "approx"
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.0267714

    Example 4.2.1 & 4.2.2 

    # See ?SignedScore
t <- pmt(
    "paired.signedscore", alternative = "greater",
    ranking_method = "with_zeros"
)

# See ?Table4.1.1
t$feed(Table4.1.1)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table4.1.1$recall_24h,
#     Table4.1.1$survey
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 2.2
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.09375

t$n_permu <- 4000
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.094

t$type <- "approx"
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.08876493

    Table 4.2.3 

    # See ?SignedScore
t <- pmt(
    "paired.signedscore", alternative = "greater",
    ranking_method = "ignore"
)

t$feed(data.frame(
    diff = c(-5, -3, -3, 0, 0, 2, 4, 4, 4, 5),
    zero = 0
))

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 1.375
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.25

t$n_permu <- 4000
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.25675

    Example 4.3.1 

    # See ?Sign
t <- pmt(
    "paired.sign", alternative = "greater"
)

t$feed(data.frame(
    diff = c(rep(+1, 12), rep(-1, 5)),
    zero = 0
))

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 12
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.07173157

t$type <- "approx"
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.07280505

    Example 4.4.1 

    # See ?RCBDANOVA
t <- pmt(
    "rcbd.anova", n_permu = 5000
)

# See ?Table4.4.3
t$feed(Table4.4.3)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table4.4.3$block_1,
#     Table4.4.3$block_2,
#     Table4.4.3$block_3,
#     Table4.4.3$block_4,
#     Table4.4.3$block_5,
#     Table4.4.3$block_6
# )


print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 110241.8
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.0502


t$type <- "approx"
# F-statistic
print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 3.121093
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.057516

    Example 4.5.2 

    # See ?Friedman
t <- pmt(
    "rcbd.friedman", n_permu = 5000
)

# See ?Table4.5.3
t$feed(Table4.5.3)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table4.5.3$block_1,
#     Table4.5.3$block_2,
#     Table4.5.3$block_3
# )

# Use SSX for speed
print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 35055.56
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.04


t$type <- "approx"
# chi-statistic
print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 250.972
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 4.032641e-54

    Example 4.6.1 

    # See ?Page
t <- pmt(
    "rcbd.page", alternative = "less", n_permu = 5000
)

# See ?Table4.4.3
t$feed(Table4.4.3)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table4.4.3$block_1,
#     Table4.4.3$block_2,
#     Table4.4.3$block_3,
#     Table4.4.3$block_4,
#     Table4.4.3$block_5,
#     Table4.4.3$block_6
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 9542
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.0038


t$type <- "approx"
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 1

    Chapter 5

    Example 5.1.1 

    # See ?Correlation
t <- pmt(
    "association.corr", method = "pearson",
    alternative = "greater", n_permu = 2000
)

# See ?Table5.1.2
t$feed(Table5.1.2)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table5.1.2$heterophils,
#     Table5.1.2$lymphocytes
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 0.8571756
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0

    Example 5.2.1 

    # See ?Correlation
t <- pmt(
    "association.corr", method = "spearman",
    alternative = "greater", n_permu = 5000
)

# See ?Table5.1.2
t$feed(Table5.1.2)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table5.1.2$heterophils,
#     Table5.1.2$lymphocytes
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 0.8968008
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0


t$type <- "approx"
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.0001088218

    Example 5.3.2 

    # See ?Correlation
t <- pmt(
    "association.corr", method = "kendall",
    alternative = "greater", type = "approx"
)

# See ?Table5.2.2
t$feed(Table5.2.2)
# or
# t$feed(
#     Table5.2.2$judge_a,
#     Table5.2.2$judge_b
# )

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 0.2599376
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.1697136

    Table 5.4.2 

    # See ?ChiSquare
t <- pmt(
    "table.chi", n_permu = 2000
)

# See ?Table5.4.2
t$feed(Table5.4.2)

print(t$statistic)
#> [1] 4.277778
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.318

t$type <- "approx"
print(t$p_value)
#> [1] 0.1177856
